title: Possible to view and takeover other user's education and courses @ mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl

profile.name: Maximum
profile.about: Maximum is a full-service agency specialised in employer branding and recruitment advertising.

vulnerability_information:
**Domain and URL:**
https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl/instellingen/gegevens/#tab2

**Summary:** IDOR vulnerability in editing education/courses 

**Description:** It is possible to view and change courses and education of other users (also known as an IDOR). It's also possible to save these, and after saving the owner of the course/education is changed to the current user and removed from the other user. 

## Browsers Verified In:
  * Chrome Version 56.0.2924.87 @ Windows 10

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Log in to mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl
  2. Go to https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl/instellingen/gegevens/#tab2 (or click the tab "Opleidingen & Cursussen" in your personal data)
  3. Add an education or course
  4. Inspect the "edit"-button of the just created course. Change the data-id to an lower ID that does not belong to you.
  5. Click the edit button from which you changed the id. A popup will open with the data of the course that is not yours.
  6. Change this data and save it. The course will now be yours, and removed from the other users profile.

I've tested it with my own two user accounts, so no data of other users is leaked or changed by me.

## Known steps to resolve:
Check if the requested course/education belongs to the user.

## Supporting Material/References:

  * https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Insecure_Direct_Object_References_(OTG-AUTHZ-004)

https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl/instellingen/gegevens/#tab2

Description: It is possible to view and change courses and education of other users (also known as an IDOR). It's also possible to save these, and after saving the owner of the course/education is changed to the current user and removed from the other user.

Browsers Verified In:

  4. Inspect the "edit"-button of the just created course. Change the data-id to an lower ID that does not belong to you.
  5. Click the edit button from which you changed the id. A popup will open with the data of the course that is not yours.
  6. Change this data and save it. The course will now be yours, and removed from the other users profile.

I've tested it with my own two user accounts, so no data of other users is leaked or changed by me.

Known steps to resolve:

Supporting Material/References:

  • https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_Insecure_Direct_Object_References_(OTG-AUTHZ-004)

Hey jorik,
Good find. I haven't validated your report but have send it to the third party involved in running mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl.
We'll have to wait for them to respond

activities.message: Hi @bamie. Educations is fixed. I can still remove courses from other people by editing my own course and changing the id in the hidden field, and then save it. The other user will loose his course this way.

activities.message: Hi @bamie, got some bad news for you.. it's still not fixed (quite disappointing after two tries and two months). Changing the ID in the hidden field to the ID of a course of someone else, I'm still able to remove the course for that user en make it mine.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @bamie, got some bad news for you.. it's still not fixed (quite disappointing after two tries and two months). Changing the ID in the hidden field to the ID of a course of someone else, I'm still able to remove the course for that user en make it mine.

activities.message: we can't reproduce it. We still see our own course. Where do you see the hidden field?
activities.markdown_message: we can't reproduce it. We still see our own course. Where do you see the hidden field?

activities.message:
I've got two users. User x has the course with ID 91759 (use the inspector in your browser to inspect the edit button, the id is available in the data-id-attribute). I change to my other user, and edit my own course (id 91761). Inside the popup, I inspect the source and change the hidden field id (<input id="id" name="id" type="hidden" value="91761">) to the Id of the other user. I click "add" and I've got a new course, and the other user just lost his course.

This is the request that is made to delete the other user his course:
```
POST /instellingen/addcursus HTTP/1.1
Host: mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl
Connection: close
Content-Length: 67
Origin: https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl
X-CSRF-TOKEN: ee0cddbc-faf6-47f6-8fc7-943f8ccca3ea
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/58.0.3029.110 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Accept: */*
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl/instellingen/gegevens/
Accept-Language: nl-NL,nl;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4
Cookie: ███████

id=91759&name=test&behaald=0&jaar=2022&omschrijving=&resultaat=test
```

To be clear, I can't see the other user his course anymore (see my comment of april 4th), but still can remove them.
activities.markdown_message:
I've got two users. User x has the course with ID 91759 (use the inspector in your browser to inspect the edit button, the id is available in the data-id-attribute). I change to my other user, and edit my own course (id 91761). Inside the popup, I inspect the source and change the hidden field id (<input id="id" name="id" type="hidden" value="91761">) to the Id of the other user. I click "add" and I've got a new course, and the other user just lost his course.

This is the request that is made to delete the other user his course:

POST /instellingen/addcursus HTTP/1.1
Host: mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl
Connection: close
Content-Length: 67
Origin: https://mijn.werkenbijdefensie.nl
X-CSRF-TOKEN: ee0cddbc-faf6-47f6-8fc7-943f8ccca3ea

Cookie: ███████

id=91759&name=test&behaald=0&jaar=2022&omschrijving=&resultaat=test

To be clear, I can't see the other user his course anymore (see my comment of april 4th), but still can remove them.

activities.message: thanks, we can reproduce it now. We'll inform the developers again.
activities.markdown_message: thanks, we can reproduce it now. We'll inform the developers again.

activities.message:
Hey Jorik,
I've got report from the third party. They explained the regression of the bug was introduced by having multiple instances of the webserver running during a deploy. A new instance would get started and the old instance should be killed. Occasionally, the sigterm didn't work and caused an old process to be kept in circulation. This should be fixed now. Can you confirm once more? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hey Jorik,
I've got report from the third party. They explained the regression of the bug was introduced by having multiple instances of the webserver running during a deploy. A new instance would get started and the old instance should be killed. Occasionally, the sigterm didn't work and caused an old process to be kept in circulation. This should be fixed now. Can you confirm once more? Thanks!

activities.message: @bamie it's fixed! Nice find for the problem :). Can you mark it as resolved?
activities.markdown_message: @bamie it's fixed! Nice find for the problem :). Can you mark it as resolved?

activities.message: Thanks for the help!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the help!

activities.message: Let's disclose this one? Could you please remove my cookie information containing a session id in one of the last comments? Thanks.
